thread.title: Why Eagles can bounce back — without Naitanui
thread.title_full: Why Eagles can bounce back — without Naitanui

title: Why Eagles can bounce back — without Naitanui
text:
Source: FOX SPORTS IT’S shaping up to be a very interesting season out west. 
Off the back of an elimination final heartbreak, the Eagles will be keen to make amends with a lift into the top four this season. 
That said, it’s a task that could well be easier said than done. 
With Nic Naitanui out for most, if not all of the upcoming season, West Coast is up against it in one sense. 
But on the other hand, the Eagles should learn from the disappointment of 2016 — plus they’ve picked up some more-than-handy recruits in the form of Sam Mitchell, Nathan Vardy and Drew Petrie. 
Naitanui may be a big loss, but the Eagles have known they’ll be without him for some time and as such, should have planned their season accordingly. 
Even without the dynamic ruckman, there is still a heap of talent at West Coast, with some players still yet to unlock their potential. 
With the likes of Luke Shuey and Jeremy McGovern in the prime of their careers, there’s plenty of reason to be optimistic heading into 2017. 
Live stream EVERY game of the JLT Community Series on FOX SPORTS. Get your free 2-week FOXTEL PLAY trial and start watching in minutes. SIGN UP NOW > 
2016 WAS … 
DISAPPOINTING, to say the least. The Eagles would have had every right to feel optimistic off the back of a grand final appearance in 2015. 
Yet they simply didn’t reach that height — in fact, they were far from it. 
The Eagles had somewhat of a reputation as flat track bullies last season — and their losses arguably reflected that. 
West Coast lost to fellow finalists Hawthorn, Sydney, Geelong, the Western Bulldogs and Adelaide — along with Collingwood — then were knocked out at home by the eventual premiers in the elimination final. 
PASS MARK 
Finals is an absolutely minimum requirement for Adam Simpson’s team in 2017. 
To put it simply, West Coast’s squad is too good not to justify a spot in the top eight. 
That said, it’s going to be very difficult to lock down a finals spot, given the amount of teams — think St Kilda and Melbourne in particular — looking to break in. The absence of Nic Naitanui for most, if not all of the season, doesn’t help. But they’ve got to plan for that. 
But with their best available players aged 25 and above, now is the window for success. 
Anything less than finals footy and it’s back to the drawing board. 
JAKE’S TAKE 
“In Mitchell, out Naitanui — that change should balance out. Overall, the Eagles are well-placed and they’re capable of pushing into the top four even if their team has less midfield strength than a few other sides. In market terms, I’d buy.” 
CHAMPION DATA SAYS … 
“While the overall list ranks third in quality, the Eagles have a big question mark hanging over their head. Their best and most influential player, Nic Naitanui, is injured for the entire season. Take him out of the equation and the quality falls to fifth. It’s not a write off, but it makes it a lot harder with the superstar out.” BUY THE BOOK. 
THE TRADE PERIOD 
The Eagles brought in experience and filled some crucial gaps with their recruiting at the end of 2016. 
The biggest headline was securing Hawthorn legend Sam Mitchell, with the onballer set to slot straight into the midfield mix. 
Meanwhile, well aware of the injury issues plaguing Naitanui and Scott Lycett, the Eagles went out and secured talented — if injury-prone — tall Nathan Vardy. To add further depth, they secured ex-Roo Drew Petrie as another ruck/forward option in the rookie draft. Sam Mitchell of the Eagles. Source: Getty Images 
In: Sam Mitchell (Hawthorn), Nathan Vardy (Geelong), Drew Petrie (Rookie Pick 29/North Melbourne), Daniel Venables (Pick 13), Josh Rotham (Pick 37), Willie Rioli (Pick 52), Jake Waterman (Pick 77), Thomas Gorter (Rookie Pick 12), Fraser McInnes (Rookie Pick 44) 
Out: Damien Cavka (Retired), Xavier Ellis (Retired), Patrick McGinnity (Retired), Kane Lucas (Retired), Jamie Bennell (Delisted), Brant Colledge (Delisted), Alec Waterman (Delisted), Corey Adamson (Delisted), Mitch Brown (Delisted) 
THE COACH 
ADAM Simpson was appointed at the end of 2013 and has coached three seasons to date. 
Across his 70-game coaching career, he has recorded 45 wins, 24 losses and one draw, with a winning percentage of 65 per cent. 
His best season as coach so far came in 2015, when he led the Eagles to a grand final appearance. 
He is contracted until the end of the 2019 season, having signed a contract extension at the end of 2015. 
The pressure’s certainly not on right now. 
THE GUN 
TAKE your pick, really. Remarkably, the Eagles have six players rated elite by Champion Data, with just about every area of the ground covered. 
That said, you can’t really go past Josh Kennedy. Josh Kennedy celebrates a goal. Picture: Sarah Reed Source: News Corp Australia 
The Eagles’ spearhead has been the picture of consistency in recent years, booting 60, 61, 80 and 82 goals over his past four seasons. 
At his best, he’s brilliant and is incredibly hard to stop, especially when he has support around him. 
But when he’s down, his team can struggle to kick a winning score. 
THE NEXT BIG THING 
He’s only played 13 games so far but Tom Barrass has already shown the potential to become a key pillar in West Coast’s defence for years to come. 
The 21-year-old key defender was exceptionally impressive in the latter part of 2016 and should kick on again this year. 
As it stands, he’s already rated ‘above average’ by Champion Data as a key defender, while he averaged an elite 2.9 intercept marks and nine spoils per game. 
With All-Australian Jeremy McGovern for company in the back six, Barrass should continue to learn, grow and improve moving forward. 
BEST 22 
B: Tom Barrass, Will Schofield, Shannon Hurn 
HB: Sharrod Wellingham, Jeremy McGovern, Brad Sheppard 
C: Andrew Gaff, Sam Mitchell, Chris Masten 
HF: Elliot Yeo, Jack Darling, Mark LeCras 
F: Jamie Cripps, Josh Kennedy, Josh Hill 
FOLL: Scott Lycett, Matt Priddis, Luke Shuey 
I/C: Mark Hutchings, Dom Sheed, Drew Petrie, Lewis Jetta 
EMG: Liam Duggan, Jack Redden, Eric Mackenzie 
OTHERS: Matthew Allen, Sam Butler, Tom Cole, Jonathan Giles, Malcolm Karpany, Tom Lamb, Kurt Mutimer, Nic Naitanui, Jackson Nelson, Luke Partington, Willie Rioli, Josh Rotham, Nathan Vardy, Daniel Venables, Jake Waterman 
ROOKIES: Tarir Bayok, Paddy Brophy, Tom Gorter, Fraser McInnes, Jordan Snadden, Simon Tunbridge, Francis Watson Nic Naitanui is out injured. Source: Supplied 
IT’S A BIG YEAR FOR … 
Elliot Yeo. After an excellent first season at West Coast, the midfielder/forward dropped off in 2016. 
Yeo averaged 16.7 disposals per game last season, down on the previous year. 
He also dropped off in terms of his contested possession numbers, along with his marks and contested marks. 
But crucially, he didn’t really improve, when at 22 (last season), improvement should have been a guarantee. 
At 23 and with 84 AFL games under his belt, Yeo should be well-equipped to bounce back with a strong season. 
Otherwise, the question marks will really come. 
SUPERCOACH MUST HAVE 
AGAIN, you can’t go past Josh Kennedy, who looms as another big point-scorer at $532,200. Players can rack up as many disposals and marks as they want, but goals are ultimately the most valuable source of SuperCoach points in the game. Kennedy has kicked more than most over recent years — and there’s no reason why he can’t top the Coleman Medal table again in 2017. 
WHY SHOULD IT BE YOUR SECOND CLUB? 
The likes of Luke Shuey, Kennedy and Jeremy McGovern make the Eagles a fun team to watch when they’re on song. 
The Eagles love to force turnovers, spread the ball and attack in waves. 
Plus, they have the potential to finish just about anywhere in the top eight, if it all comes together. 
It would make for a fun, if frustrating ride. View All Comments The latest sports news, in your inbox daily. Email
